<div class="subscriber-preview"><p>For the second time in about five months, St. Clair residents
are expected to receive a letter from the Department of Natural
Resources saying that a routine water test has come back showing
contamination in the system.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-preview"><p>The latest letter is scheduled to be mailed sometime this week
after Public Works Director Brian Otten said a water test conducted
last month showed higher levels of coliform bacteria.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Otten informed aldermen, Mayor Ron Blum and other city officials
of the situation on Monday night during the regularly scheduled
board meeting.</p>
</div>

</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>He also said he believes the city's drinking water remains
safe.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>"There is no cause for alarm," Otten told The Missourian after
Monday's meeting. "I don't believe the problem is in our system. I
wish I knew what caused this. It could be a shifting in the earth
or something like that. Right now, we just don't know, but we do
believe our water is OK."</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>The DNR letter will explain to residents what transpired with
the routine October test and what the city has done since.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>"I do want to make sure our drinking water is safe for our
residents," Blum said. "We will do everything we can to ensure
that."</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>In April, a similar situation occurred at one of the city's
wells. In early June, a letter from the DNR was sent to residents
explaining that situation. City officials emphasized at that time
as well that there was no cause for alarm, and no boil order or
advisory was issued.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Otten said on Monday he believes there is no reason to boil
water this time either.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>What Happened</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Otten said the city tests its water supply at five locations
monthly. One of the locations tested in mid-October was the
drinking fountain at city hall.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>"That test came back positive for coliform," he said.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>A second test was conducted at the same site a couple of days
later with the same result.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Procedure dictates that additional samples then must be taken
"upstream" and "downstream" from the test site that showed
contamination. Water at Patton's Nursery, 785 N. Commercial Ave.,
and the Coleman Chiropractic office, 605 N. Commercial, was tested,
and both showed the same contamination.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>"They both were positive," Otten said. "That's what triggered
all of this."</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Otten said when repeat samples must be done, each of the city's
six wells are tested, too. All of them except for Well No. 1 near
the American Legion came back clean.</p>
</div>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset, stf","fold":"span","include_domain":null,"size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/emissourian.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news"}' style="display:none;"></div>

</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>"So, we flushed Well No. 1 for four to five hours and basically
then retested everything again," Otten said. "At that time,
everything (additional tests) came back fine."</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>But because two consecutive tests showed contamination, the DNR
letter must be sent, he said.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>The letter sent to residents in June stated that "our water
system recently violated a drinking water standard for April 2011.
Although this is not an emergency, as our customers you have a
right to know what happened, what you should do and what we are
doing to correct this situation."</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>The problem at that time was at Well No. 2. Repairs were made to
the unit and it went back online at the end of July after tests
came back absent of coliform.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Officials were confident then that the contamination came from
the well itself and not from the city's water supply.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>The June letter also stated that boiling drinking water "is
usually not deemed necessary," and that if the situation was an
emergency, residents would have been contacted immediately.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Otten said this new letter should basically say the same
things.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>A water sample from the Orchard Park area also came back showing
some contamination, Otten said, but the retest came up
negative.</p>
</div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Coliforms are bacteria that are always present in the digestive
tracts of animals, including humans, and are found in their wastes.
They are also found in plant and soil material.</p>
</div>

      Wenham Water Will Be Continue to Be Chlorinated    </h1>
<h2 class="h4">The Wenham Water Board and Water Department have heard a few complaints about taste of water since the boil water order last month.</h2> <div class="clearfix summary-additional">

<div class="content-body center-block" id="article-wrapper">
<p>Wenham water may not taste as good as it did before last month's for at least six months - if ever.</p> <p>To make sure there is no new E. coli in the water wells or distribution pipes, the Wenham Water Board for the first time is injecting sodium hydrocholoride into the water as an interim measure.</p> <p>That chemical bleaches the water, making it safe to drink. But it makes the water have a different taste and odor.</p> <p>Water Board Chairman Ernest Ashley and Board member Richard Quateman said Thursday night they had heard a few complaints about the taste of the water. Water superintendent Erik Mansfield said the had gotten a few complaints, "but not too many."</p> <p>The water department does not know what caused the last month.</p> <p>"We have a very tight system," Ashley said. The water wells have filters and are well protected. So the water department's investigation continues to pinpoint the cause so it can be protected in the future.</p> <p>The town went on a boil water order when tests found E. coli in the water. E. coli comes from fecal contaimination and can make humans sick.</p> <p>The water department will meet Monday with the state Department of Environmental Protection to determine what options the town has to run what the state perceives to be a safe drinking water system.</p> <p>Complying with tougher federal Environmental Protection Agency standards for drinking water, the state DEP will probably require Wenham to inject chlorine in the water indefinitely.</p> <p>Quateman said the town has been fortunate to go this long without the state requiring that it inject chlorine in the water.</p> <p>"It is a done deal. We have to do something," Ashley said.</p> <p>Some chlorine products, using calcium hydrocholorite, cause less of an odor or can be tasted in the water, Mansfield told the board. If approved by the DEP, those systems could be installed along with some structural changes in the piping by late spring, in time for a higher water usage during the summer months, Ashley said.</p> <p>The cost of putting in a calcium hydrocholorite feeder system at the pumping station is not known. But it would likely cost enough that the water board would have to ask the town at the spring Town Meeting for approval.</p> <p>The board may also have to consider raising the water rates, Mansfield said.</p> <p>The water department would like to consider other alternatives to chlorine, but injecting ozone or shining ultraviolet light on the water would be far more expensive, Mansfield said.</p><div id="in-article-boxed-recirc"><div class="text-center air-md"><a category="subscribe" class="btn btn-lg btn-cta-alt pill sans in-article-subscribe l-bold" href="/" trigger="article_button_click">   Subscribe  <span aria-hidden="true" class="fal fa-angle-right fa-lg"></span></a></div></div> </div>

Boil-water order in effect in west suburbs

November 15, 2011 3:13:39 PM PST
November 15, 2011 (LEYDEN TOWNSHIP, Ill.) --
Thousands of west suburban residents are being advised to boil their water for the next few days.

Officials in Leyden Township near Franklin Park say IDOT crews working on the Fullerton Avenue bridge over Silver Creek damaged the water main running through the creek bed.

Because of the damage, a boil order is in effect for more than 12,000 residents in the township.

The boil order is in effect for the next 72 hours until 10:30 Friday morning.

Residents are urged to boil their water before cooking or drinking.

Boil Water Order In Tekonsha

Monday, November 14, 2011 6:24 a.m. EST by Pat Thomas

TEKONSHA, MI (WTVB) - The residents of the village of Tekonsha are being advised by health officials that they should boil their tap water before ingesting it.  Routine testing showed unacceptably high levels of Coli form bacteria in the water on Friday and Saturday.  

Testing will be done daily until the situation is resolved.  Tests on the water coming out of the two wells used by the village are clean.  The problem is somewhere in the system itself, which may have to be disinfected and flushed.

Residents can either boil or buy the water they drink until the tests show it’s safe again.  The Michigan Department of Environmental Quality is working with the Village Dept. of Public Works to fix the problem.

Boil-water order lifted for part of Harnett County

Posted November 14, 2011

Get a new code
You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters

Fuquay-Varina, N.C. — The Harnett County Public Utilities department lifted a boil-water order Monday afternoon for northwest Harnett County.

The order was issued late Sunday for areas near Duncan after some customers lost service or experienced low pressure.
